results.title: A Kiwi in exile
results.brief_description: Short film made in 1958 by Graham Foster to send to his relatives in New Zealand. Structured as a comic ‘ Day in the life’, the film features footage of Melbourne city and St Kilda and a constant wisecracking narrative from Foster. Of special interest is the segment on Foster’s working day at a Melbourne television station featuring the behind-the-scenes action. As television did not reach New Zealand until 1960, this short film was the easiest way to demonstrate to his family, exactly what he did in Australia.

results.title: A Kite story
results.creator_credit: Churchill Films and Pieter Van Deusen
results.brief_description: A story about a boy, two kites, and a stranger who makes the kites. He gives the boy a small white kite, to which he is very attached until he sees the glittering rocket kite…The tale is adventure and fantasy, and indicates the values of friendship and loyalty.

results.title: A Kind of seeing: the colour of Scotland
results.creator_credit: IFA (Scotland), Films of Scotland and Edward McConnell
results.brief_description: An abstract colour impression of Scotland throughout the four seasons of the year. The camera focused on flowers, the surface of ponds and the winter sky. There is no commentary, the background music was composed by Frank Spedding.

results.title: A Kind of loving
results.creator_credit: Anglo Amalgamated, Waterhall, Vic Films, Joseph Janni and John Schlesinger
results.brief_description: Schlesinger’s feature debut is a starkly photographed study of a young man in the north of England dreaming of escape from the drudgery of work, only to find himself entering into a loveless marriage when his girlfriend becomes pregnant. This gritty realistic film was part of a new wave in English cinema and arts which concentrated on the experiences of the generation of working class people born during the so-called “boom years” of post-war capital. Alan Bates is outstanding in the lead role. Based on the novel by Stan Barstow.

results.title: A Killing rain (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: BBC-TV, United Nations Environment Programme and Jeremy Taylor
results.brief_description: Acid rain is one aspect of environmental pollution discussed at the Public Hearing in London in 1982. This program travels from Scotland to Scandinavia to West Germany to uncover background causes and the effects of this major pollution problem of the 80s.

results.title: A Kid called Troy
results.creator_credit: Carlyon and Rivette Pictures, Michael J. Rivette and Terry Carlyon
results.brief_description: A profoundly moving and inspirational sequel to the critically acclaimed “Suzi’s Story”. It is the story of Vince and Troy Lovegrove, the father and son who survived Suzi when she died from AIDS in 1987. Troy carried the AIDS virus from birth. This is Troy’s story - the story of what it is to be seven, to love life as only a child can and yet to be a victim of AIDS.

results.title: A Kibbutz
results.brief_description: Gives a brief history of the establishment of the kibbutz. Describes community organisation, and the changing role of women on the kibbutz. Shows the progress of a child through the system. Discussion ensues when two of the haberim wish to leave the kibbutz - problems and advantages are aired.

results.title: A Jury of her peers
results.brief_description: A farmer is found strangled in bed and his wife is accused of the murder. As the sheriff, prosecuting attorney and a neighbour search the farm for clues, their women, hardly leaving the kitchen, uncover the most crucial details about this shattered family…even the motive for the murder. Unknown to the men, they act as the accused woman’s sole jury - a true jury of her peers. Based on a short story written in 1917 by Susan Glaspell.
